reviews: 08Jul2022 Sweet citrus fruits, lemon, sweet grain and cereal malts, wheat, esters. Slightly hazy gold, medium, creamy, white head. Light bitter. Sweet grain and cereal malts, wheat, esters, bread, lemon, soft carb, med bod. A malty, lemony mess. Bottle at American Airlines Flagship Lounge, Jamaica.

Bottle from Food Dog near the lake, finished by me because my wife hated it and called it a bad Radler. Light yellow gold, good head. Lemon peel nose with wheaty goodness. Malty, a bit too sweet, hard to distinguish if the lemony flavor is hop or citrus fruit but I guess it's a blend of the two. Decent wheat notes.

A hazed blonde ale with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet fruity malt with light lime. In mouth, sweet fruity lime mix with light mineral notes, ok if a bit boring. Bottle.

Hazy golden ale with a thick collapsing white head. Aroma is sweet lemony, with notes of  oranges. In mouth, light fresh wheat beer, with definite orange peels, and lactic sourness. A bit chalky. Lighter bodied summer wheat.  Bottle is about 6 months old.

12 oz. bottle pours a slightly hazy golden yellow color with modest white head and not much lacing. Aroma has wheat, lemon, orange peel and light spices.  Body is light to medium with average carbonation.  Easy to drink, and appropriate for a hot summer day.

12oz bottle someone left at my house, consumed from the bottle.  Nose has some lemon and coriander, sour wheat, some sweat.  Flavor is a bit fake, sour, lemon, some salt, some grist and straw.  Finishes mostly dry, medium tartness.
Bright and hazy orange on pour with a small white head. Lots of sweet citrus aromas and full of ripe fruity flavours.

Slightly hazy gold with a thin foamy white head. Nice delicate aroma with a touch of orange peel and maybe some lemon notes on a pale wheaty base. Smooth balanced and semidry flavor that’s pale and gently wheaty with a nice noble hop character and gentle citrusy undertones.

Clear straw yellow color, no head.  Smelled like spice, lemongrass and wheat.  Taste was clean and crisp, albiet light bodied. A delightful surprise from a macrobrew!

Draft at Moriartys. Hazy golden pour. Citrusy wheat beer. Orange. Vanilla. Banana. Oyster crackers. Marshmallow circus peanuts. Medium body. Easy drinking but feels a bit silly sweet and annoying.

Taste is sweet up front with emerging citrus notes, musters a crisp finish with stronger citrus, slight hoppiness and mild peppery notes. The pepper at the end is good. 12 oz. bottle.  AROMA: Sweet and lemony, like a lemon-head candy.  APPEARANCE: Pours a hazy pale gold with a whispy-thin white head that dissipates quickly.  TASTE: Lightly sour with a very mild lemon flavor and a hint of lime on the back-end.  MOUTHFEEL: Medium-bodied with a slightly course texture. Carbonation is average and the finish is mild.  OVERALL: Slightly better than the previous version of this beer (i.e pre-2019), but not by much. I would have never tried this newer version if I had not gotten it for free. That is how bad the old version was. While this version has improved, it remains the worst beer that Samuel Adams makes, and one that I still won't buy. Which is a shame, because I like all of their other beers that I've tried.

12 oz. bottle. AROMA: Mild lemon scent and nothing else. APPEARANCE: Pours a cloudy, deep gold, with a white, frothy head that dissipates slowly. TASTE: Lightly sour with flavors of dish-water (don’t ask me how I know) and lemon. PALATE: Medium bodied with a thin texture. Carbonation is average and there’s not much of a finish. OVERALL: Full disclosure: I had a nice Eisbock prior to trying this beer. So maybe that threw off my palate. But I did try a palate cleansing before trying this beer. Having said that, I find this beer severely lacking. The taste is just short of horrific and the other aspects (aroma, palate, etc.) are below par. Which is a shame, because I tend to like most of the Samuel Adams beers.

Decided to try a bottle of this at a family reunion when I heard that they had changed the recipe for this brew; amazing how distinctly different this from what I remember of the prior rendition of this summer ale! The lemon and lime flavors are indeed much more pronounced in the aroma and the taste, to the point that any subtle wheaty or malty flavors are smothered. Despite the continued hazy appearance, this is noticeably lighter and thinner on the palate, with an almost acidic aftertaste of lime juice in the finish. Some peppery notes to it, but less pronounced than before. Too much lemon and lime for my taste, although it’s not offensive I would not ever remotely consider buying this for myself. Sadly more “meh” from Samuel Adams.

Pours a hazy medium yellow with a white head that last leaving litle lacing. Nose is strongly lemon in the can. In the glass, the nose was attenuated but still lemon with no detectable spice except in the aftertaste . Obviously, Boston Beer is keeping to its tradition of brewing beer to the widest demographic with this and Sam '76. They are not "bad" beers but they represent a chasing after market share and NOT what makes "craft" beer what it became and is. So, I am saddened that Boston Beer decided to lower the flavor profile based on demographics. While I do not dislike this beer but it is not what it was. Surprisingly, their advertising was honest. It is lighter.  4/14/21: Re-tasting revealed citrus dominates. Balance is not in the equation. Again, it is not what it was. As designed, it is drinkable but with an ABV that belies it is a "summer" beer despite its light flavor profile and low IBUs. 12 oz bottle BBY 12/21.

Samuel Adams Summer Ale 
ABV - 5.3  $2.20 12oz bottle

Appearance - Golden yellow, thick off-white head. hazy with some visible carbonation. (2/3)


Aroma - Bubble gum wheat beer scent. Grainy, yeasty. Notes of orange peel, lemon zest, banana peel. Not getting much spice. (7/12)

Taste - Citrus forward. Wheat beer flavor in full effect. Very subtle spice. Notes of orange peel and caramel malts. (11/20) 

Mouthfeel - Smooth, silky feel. Nice medium body, easy drinking (Drinkability 3+). Has a good feel to it, full but not heavy. Carbonation is just right, not overpowering. (4/5)

Overall - You won't be blown away, but this beer will never disappoint. Just solid and very easy to drink. (6/10)

very light flavor with no real presence of any taste other than the hops.

UPDATE 06/30/2021 -  Tried this again due to a "pick 6" dept. of the local grocery store.  Again, taste is light without any real distinct flavor. The hops were not as pronounced, but were still obvious.  Typical "great" USA "crafty" beer.  Yuck.  If craft brewing simply means you add 150 lbs of hops to each bottle, no thanks.  I want a beer, not a hops drink.  Yes, hops is in beer, but not to the degree that USA "craft" brewers think is "good".  It isnt.  They even add too much to their Octoberfest beers - WHICH, BY DEFINITION, ARE A MALT BEER.    USA craft beers = garbage.  Thank you Germany for maintaining your beers, to some degree, as beers and not some fad idea.

BBD: 9/2017

2015 BJCP Category: 30A Spice/Herb/Vegetable Beer (base style: 1D American Wheat Beer)


AROMA: Bready/wheaty base malt is moderately strong along with a citrusy lemon garnish. Slight spicy scent as well. No hops or esters (none needed) 9/12

APPEARANCE: Dark golden hue over a hazy, bubbly body. Moderate white foam mostly dissipates. Decent retention and lacing. 2/3

FLAVOR: A bready/dough taste accounts for a strong portion of the palette; though a strong spicy flavor is almost as prominent. Interesting balance of lightly sweet wheat taste and mild tingling spice. Lemon flavor emerges as it finishes which complements the previous characteristics quite well. Some lingering malt and spice flavors, but otherwise clean. No hop presence to speak of; no esters either. 17/20

MOUTHFEEL: Medium body and carbonation; more smooth than crisp. Somewhat refreshing; though it’s a bit heavy at 5.3% ABV to work as a true session beer. A little less alcohol and body would be totally crushable. 4/5

OVERALL IMPRESSION: I used to dislike this, but now I appreciate it as a classic American Wheat Beer + spice. It’s what a summer beer should be. 8/10

TOTAL SCORE: 40/50

On tap at Iavarone, Long Island. Hazy rusty yellow with substantial white head and nice lacing. Aroma is sort of adjunct lager, bit of wheat and citrus, nothing substantial. Flavor is light wheat, fairly floury, sort of corn flavor. Light Nitro-like mouthfeel. Not gonna be a go-to summer beer.
A light wheat ale, that is easy to drink, only a slight yeast aroma and flavour.
Draft at Joe’s. Pours orange gold with a white head. Flavor is wheat, orange, lemon. A bit of pepper in the finish.

Pours a cloudy pale yellow the color of pineapples. No head to speak of, just a very tiny ring of white bubbles. Smells of apples, floral hops, some bready fruitiness I can’t place. Maybe those are the grains of paradise? In the flavor, a heavy wheat flavor, with some subtle citrus and spicy notes. Very mild sweetness. Light body, no bitterness. Summer Ale isn’t fantastic by any means, but it is the taste of the season. What is it about wheat that’s so good during summer?

12 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, best before 11/2014. Pours hazy bright golden color with a 1-2 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of lemon, orange, apricot, pear, apple, coriander, pepper, wheat, cracker, bread, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance of pale malt, spice, and yeast ester notes; with solid strength. Taste of lemon, orange, apricot, pear, apple, coriander, pepper, wheat, cracker, bread, light honey, herbal, grass, and yeast earthiness. Minimal herbal spice bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, orange, apricot, pear, apple, coriander, pepper, wheat, cracker, bread, light honey, and herbal/yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Good balance and robustness of pale malt, spice, and yeast ester flavors; with a great malt/yeast/spice balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, and lightly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with zero warming present after the finish as expected of 5.3%. Overall this is a nice spiced pale wheat ale style. All around good balance and robustness of pale malt, spice, and yeast ester flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.
Interesting I thought I had it already rated. It was thin and easy to drink with that nice tickling sensation of Sam Adams’ beers.

How: Bottle Appearance: hazy orange, white head. Aroma: floral, lemon peel, wheat, grass Palate : light body, average carbonation.

Pours a slightly hazy yellow with lots of head. Nicely carbonated good mouthfeel, but slightly medicinal tasting.

Appearance: Slightly hazy body that is a medium shade of golden yellow with a fluffy white head that leaves ample lacing.

Aroma: It has a sickly sour aroma that is not very inviting. There is a bit of lemon zest but not very fresh smelling.

Taste: There are some good qualities and some bad. I put it this way because at first I really did not like this drink, but some of it started to warm up to me. There is this flavor that tastes a bit like what I can only assume dishwater tastes like. There is this lemon twang and this muddy mess of sickly tasting flavors like old vegetables in the refrigerator. On a positive note there is a smooth wheat flavor that tries to come to the rescue at the end. If I had a 2 second memory I would probably really enjoy this beer.

Palate: The palate for this beer is pretty bad. The combination of flavors makes it undrinkable to me.

Overall: I find this to be a beer of poor quality that I would not recommend or drink again.

Transfer from BA review 5-6-12- 
Poured from bottle into pint glass

Appearance – Pours a hazy golden-orange color with a big white head. The head fades over about a 5 min time frame to give a medium level of lacing.

Smell – A nice wheat and lemon aroma are the base of the smell. These are mixed with a lighter orange and spicy smell as well.

Taste – A wheat bread taste is nice and heavy up front. This nice wheat flavor is the base of the beer and lasts throughout the taste. At the start the taste is on the sweeter side with flavors of orange and some sugar sweetness. These flavors give way a bit to some more sour/bitter lemon flavors and a mild spice toward the middle and the end. Very full flavored overall.

Mouthfeel – The body is quite heavy for the abv of the beer, with a carbonation level that is a bit on the higher side. All in al, the two combined to match the characteristics of the beer well. The carbonation creates a refreshing experience while the body accentuates the nice citrus and wheat flavors.

Overall –A great tasting and refreshing beer great for sitting outside.

Citrus and fresh wheat, with a blend of lemon zest, light fruits and hints of black pepper. Very crisp making it a good choice on a warm summer day.

Samuel Adams has often made the mistake of being heavy-handed when it comes to adding exotic elements to wheat ales. Summer Ale does not suffer from that malady as much as some of the other beers. The spices are more reserved, here. Yet, they are fairly flavorful. The lemon zest is used nicely in this brew. While traditional wheat ales are more satisfying on a summer day, this ale would also make a decent choice.

This beer just made my top 10 best beers of all time. Outstanding taste!! Perfect warm weather beer. It has a solid body and plenty of flavor (lemon, wheat) but its not over-powering with the hops that Sam Adams tends oversell. If you dont like this beer, then you wont like any beer.

4 oz. from bottle at a Sam Adams dinner/beer pairing benefit at Old Line Wine's The Bistro in Beltsville, MD. 

Lightly hazy, light straw color with an off-white head and good lacing. 

Very light aroma of lemon and wheat. 

Light taste of lemon, wheat and herbs. 

Light/medium body and medium/high carbonation. 

Not much here to especially enjoy, but nothing bad here.  I just found it to be a boring beer.

On tap. Definately taste the citrus but not overpowering. I think I could drink a few of these after mowing. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a golden color with a white head.  Grassy aroma with a hint of floral hop, lemon, and some spices.  Flavor is all grass and earthy tones with some lemon and not much else. Not really a very good summer beer.

12 fl oz / 355mL bottle into a Samuel Adams glass. Served cold.

Aroma: Lemons. Sour wheat. Maybe some spice. Smells pretty refreshing.

Appearance: A hazy, barely translucent dark yellow with a persistent soapy, white head.

Taste: Pretty lemony! A little sweet even. Definite wheat presence. Very nice.

Palate: Not heavy, but not thin or watery at all; light and refreshing, but with nice character.

Overall: A good summer ale indeed. The lemon flavor doesn’t overpower and make this sickly sweet or super lemony. It’s a good, lemony beer.
Lager glass. Hints of apricot, lemons and wheat. Cloudy gold, lots of carbonation bubbles but that’s it. Apricot taste with a bit of wheat. A little watered down.
On draught during a brewery tour. One of the worst things I have tasted from Sam and I know it was fresh because I had it at the brewery. Bland, watery and just not good.
Its a decent beer, but i wouldnt classify it as a good wheat beer.  Its a hazy yellow with minimal head and no lacing.  Almost no wheat taste and a little to crisp to be a wheat
Used to think this was my favorite summer ale, how things have changed, will always make me think of summer though

Slightly hazy yellow beer.  Tart astringent nose with a little basement yeast.  Tastes of rye-like spice, belgian yeast, brine and some basement.  Slight mouth puckering effect but not tart as it smells.  This one’s good.

Not bad. On draft at the Outback. No rules...just right. Served in a big bloke (24oz mug) twice. Aroma was light tropical fruit. Peaches, lemon, citrus, wheat and grain, and sweet honey. Pour is golden orange with a foamy white head. Taste matches up, being a touch on the sweet side. A good dose of wheat on the finish with lemon and citrus notes throughout. Not a bad drinker.
Draft at the brewery. Pours cloudy amber orange with a light foamy head. Has the ancient grains of paradise. Medium body. Tastes like wheat with hints of orange. Smells like citrus and herbs.

Tap at brewery. Pours hazy gold with thick, frothy white head; good retention and some lacing. Aroma is cereal and biscuit malts, citrus fruit, lemon peel, floral hops, light spice, and light herbs. Flavor is sweet, bready malts forward with supporting light fruit esters, citrus and floral hops, and some herbs; dry finish. Light body and low carbonation.

Bottle at noodle zoo... pours orange very cloudy.. clean fresh aroma...taste is probably one if the best summer ales ive had in a long time.. will probsbly go pick up a 6 of this... good breakfast beer
Aromas of lemon candy, orange peel, and wild flowers.  Hazy orange with a lasting, white head.  Dry, fruity, citrusy, and biscuity.  Light body, smooth, with zippy carbonation, and a clean finish.
